column7: Gennario Lombardi opened his shop in Soho in 1905—the first pizzeria in the U.S. It’s hard to vouch for how the pizzas tasted a century ago, but there’s more elbow room now after a renovation, if not the charm of the old joint. Still, Lombardi’s continues to bake a hot contender for best pie.

column7: Since 1975, Raoul’s has been serving first-rate French fare in an authentic bistro setting, filled with antique furnishings, pressed-tin ceilings and walls, and black-and-white leather booths. Parents with a modest sensibility may want to situate their kids away from the paintings of female nudes. The food is as inviting as the atmosphere. Magret duck breast is sliced and served over kale and carrot puree, and a thick, charred cut of sirloin smothered in black-peppercorn sauce is the tender and tasty.

column7: The burgers at this dimly lit Village standby are legendary, and the New Yorkers who love them legion—which can make for long lines on occasion. Yankees on the tube, and a jukebox that plays everything from Calexico to Coltrane, can help pass the time, though. Go for the Bistro Burger, a fat patty of broiled beef, cheese and smoky bacon on a sesame-seed bun for $6.75. A plate of crisp shoestring fries will set you back only $2.50.

column7: It’s not rude to point at Elvie’s; it’s expected. Turo-turo means “point-point” in Tagalog, and that’s how you order, selecting from the Filipino dishes on display. Choose the chicken adobo, tender meat in a sweet-and-sour sauce of vinegar, soy and star anise, and take it to one of the slim red wooden tables. Don’t leave without sampling one of our favorite Cheap Eats sweets: The Halo Halo is a vertical miracle—a tall glass cradling layers of crushed ice, milk, sweet beans and golden jackfruit topped with an orb of vanilla ice cream.

column7: Since 1995, crowds have been vying for seats beneath this trattoria’s canopy of red Christmas lights. Although a slew of cut-rate Italian eateries have since joined the East Village neighborhood, diners still endure long waits and blasé service for a stab at Il Bagatto’s affordable, well-executed dishes. Of course, there are worse places to wait than the woodsy bar, where a ceiling of tangled branches hovers above patrons sipping from a selection of 10 by-the-glass wines and 60 bottled choices. Once seated, the room is so tightly packed, it’s hard to resist sticking your fork in your neighbor’s gnochetti verdi e blu (spinach gnocchi in Gorgonzola sauce). The tiny open kitchen also makes garlicky mussels and tagliolini with a seafood-laden tomato sauce. It’s great for a big family dinner on Sunday, when you can order meaty homestyle specials like lasagna, and osso buco with mashed potatoes.

column7: A throwback to the artsy, affordable East Village of decades past, this Ukrainian diner is famous for such authentic savory grub as borscht, kielbasa and pierogi. Homemade treats like blintzes, poppy-seed bread and rice pudding will send your sweet tooth (or toothless sweetie) to heaven. Factor in fast, friendly service and lots of vegetarian options, and this landmark more than earns its cheery, inclusive appellation: Veselka means “rainbow” in Ukrainian.

column7: Cuban cooking finds its Zen at Asia de Cuba. The menu is a careful combination of Asian inflections and Cuban flavor, a concept most successful in seafood dishes like the calamari salad with banana, cashews and orange sesame dressing. Beef dumplings are steamed with coconut rice for island flavor, while traditional Cuban entrées like roast pork nod to the East with their pairing with bok choy. The Philippe Starck–designed bi-level restaurant, a sea of white with subtle hints of amber and orange, features a balcony-like lounge and dining area overlooking a giant communal table downstairs.

column7: New York City was once a world-renowned oyster town, and this beloved 90-year-old landmark, nestled in Grand Central’s lower level, reminds diners of that former glory. Two large rooms flank a white-topped counter where eaters can choose from around 30 varieties of bivalves. Kids may be more interested in one of the famously huge desserts: The apple pie bursts forth with razor-thin slices of fruit.

column7: Cinder-block walls and polished concrete floorsadd to the industrial-chic decor at this well-loved Billyburg standby; there’s even room for installation art, like a suspended rowboat fountain. Sushi chefs and a Japanese hibachi operation have materialized to adda little Pan-Asian pizzazz: The Williamsburg Bridge combo is a colorful, show-stopping platter loaded with hand rolls, sushi and sashimi. Still, nothing takesaway from the freshness and low prices that madethis spot popular in the first place.

column7: This particular rinconcito (“little corner”) compensates for its humble decor and short staffing with a remarkable range of entrées sure to thrill any starch addict. Potatoes make appearances in all forms, and some dishes, such as the saltado (chicken or beef marinated in soy sauce with onions and tomatoes), are served with generous portions of both fries and white rice. Corn also plays a starring role, in the popular chicha morada drink (purple corn juice) and in dishes such as the not-to-be-missed tamale appetizer—a comforting heap of juicy meats smothered in steaming corn masa.

Radio Roll-Ups) with roasted veggies are uniformly overstuffed—you may toddle out feeling the same way.

column7: Although known for buckwheat noodles, the menu here is ever-evolving. (Pre-teen boys may be either delighted or horrified to learn of salted squid guts.) Vinegary konnyaku, gelatinous arum root and smoky kinpira gobo (burdock root) make exotic beginnings to a meal of one of dozens of soba or udon dishes, served hot or cold in an unbeatable fish-based stock. Vegan options are available as well. Desserts can be pleasantly unorthodox, such as a bowl of vanilla ice cream spiked with wasabi and honey.

column7: On weekend mornings, a “We love kids!” attitude and a no-reservations policy add up to pleasant, barely controlled chaos. Little ones and adults alike will enjoy savory treats such as the alphabet chicken soup, mac and cheese, salads and slow-cooked barbecue. We also adore the enormous Dumbo location (1 Main St between Plymouth and Water Sts, Brooklyn; 718-222-0666), which is directly across the street from a swell playground with Manhattan skyline views.

column7: Bright, clean and always on the ball, Nyonya is a model of Chinese-Malay efficiency: The cheerful staff zooms customers through seating, feeding and paying up, to make room for the next hungry crew. Take in the bamboo-hut charm while you can; the passing parade of roti canai (layered flatbread served with a chicken gravy for dipping), nasi lemak (coconut rice) and battered-and-fried whole fish drizzled in spicy-sweet sauce will be a delicious distraction. Even the burger-and-fries set will find something to eat on the extensive menu, like mild pineapple fried rice. The downside to a speedy kitchen that serves everything hot? A burned tongue from wolfing it all down.

column7: Plenty of places do fancy. Two Toms ain’t one of them. Jimmy Catapano and his son, Tom, serve excellent food like manicotti—thin homemade pancakes rolled and stuffed with ricotta, mozzarella, Parmesan and parsley. You won’t find it listed on a menu—there isn’t one. The waiters will fill you in on the day’s selections, including a pork chop known in this neck of the woods for its Paul Bunyan-size proportions (veal dishes are more modestly sized). Wine and soft drinks are snatched from a deli-style fridge in the dining room, and they’re all ice-cold.

column7: If you’re making a day of seeing a Broadway matinee, add Victor’s Café to the itinerary. The kitschy space is like a set—straw fans, celeb photos and tropical foliage. Sample the authentic Cuban crackers and dense bread on your table, then dig in to the bartolito, a sweet plantain stuffed with pork hash and served in a black-bean sauce. Entrées are huge and tasty: The spicy seafood casserole is packed with shrimp, scallops, snapper and clams; the vaca frita is panfried tender shredded beef. For dessert, share the piña y helado: minors can scoop up the vanilla ice cream while you down the pineapple chunks broiled in dark rum.

column7: Less glittering boîte than rakish hang, this workhorse has the quintessential bistro vibe; distressed mirrors, a copper-topped bar and dull wooden floors round out the worn-in decor. Tourists and Soho habitués chill over tasty standards like warm lentil salad, steak frites and croque-monsieur, all haphazardly flopped on plates with nary a garnish in sight. The prices are reasonable and the flavors familiar, which is how the regulars like it.

column7: Getting a table under Carmine’s mismatched chandeliers is tough, even by Theater District standards. Once you do snag a spot, you’ll be greeted by an amicable staff that dishes out gigantic portions of family-style specialties. Chicken comes slathered in savory marsala sauce, and eggplant parmigiana is thickly layered with tomato sauce and bubbling cheese. Enormous desserts (like the aptly named Titanic, a sundae atop a chocolate torte) verge on the obscene, and the odds are high that you will hear “Happy Birthday” sung more than once.

column7: It’s not the simple blue-and-white Hellenic decor or the plastic fish on the walls that lure crowds to this Astoria taverna. The glistening display of fresh seafood destined to be your dinner is what keeps diners coming. Elias’s grilled fish is exceptional even in a neighborhood packed with Greek restaurants. Those in the know order the swordfish kebabs, fired up simply with green peppers, onions and tomatoes. Dessert isn’t served on weekends, but keep an eye peeled for the occasional special of <em>loukoumades,<i/> delectable sweet dough fritters drizzled in honey.

column7: If you’re used to North Indian fare, the casually elegant Pongal will fill in a few blanks with dishes from the South. Staff at this kosher vegetarian spot provide a brief culinary geography lesson and realistically assess how scorching the “hot spices” really are—especially helpful when dealing with tender young palates. Condiments are exceptional, superfresh, and ideal for dipping the idli (steamed rice cakes) and medu vada (lentil doughnuts). The dosa are big and finely seasoned. The truly great tuver baingan has refreshingly unmushy eggplant, pigeon peas and an unforgettable bite that just might bring you back for more.

column7: It’s not just the decor that’s calming at Surya: Many of the regional favorites here are subtle, too, without being boring—something that plays well with younger, heat-sensitive palates. Spicy, marinated baby lamb chops (with a foil-wrapped “handle” for easy maneuvering) are cooked in the tandoor, which enhances the sweet taste of tamarind sauce. Meen molee (crisp sautéed halibut served in a coconut-ginger sauce) gently combines flavors without making you gasp for water. Try the Indian version of a tasting menu: the weekend buffet lunch or the daily $6.95 lunch box to go. A swell crowd takes over at night, but the staff is sweet and accommodating to young customers who dine early.

column7: The signature dish here is pitza–a pizzalike savory treat with a pita-dough crust–served glistening straight from the brick over. Picky tots will love the tomato-and-cheese ($8) variety, while those more adventurous will appreciate the lahambajin ($8), topped with ground lamb, tomato and parsley. Be sure to order a selection of meze for the table, such as a spinach and chickpea salad ($5) and foul, an earthy blend of flat fava beans, parsley, tomatoes and garlic ($5); sop it up with fresh-baked pita ($1) or spicy za’atar bread ($6).

column7: Chelsea has changed a lot in the past few decades, but one thing remains, more or less, blissfully the same: the chrome comfort of this Art Deco–style diner which has been serving blue-plate specials since 1976. Here, kids nosh on finger foods like quesadillas and pigs-in-a-blanket or platters such as a juicy blue-cheese steak burger or BBQ chicken with mashed potatoes. Desserts surpass diner standards, especially the thick, mousselike chocolate pudding.

column7: Even though soups are featured prominently on its kosher menu, the prospect of visiting such a simply monikered joint in this otherwise impersonable, gray neighborhood did not exactly have us salivating. It was a great surprise, then, to find a spacious, comfortable, beautifully Art Deco-styled and super-child-friendly oasis. Boasting four kinds of quintessential chicken soup–chicken and rice, along with three varieties of chicken-noodle (plain, with beef-filled kreplach or with a matzo ball)–plus a mushroom-barley and an always-changing soup of the day, this is a must-visit soup spot for kids. If you’re not a carnivore (even the mushroom soup is meat-based), you needn’t be left out in the cold: Tasty small-plate vegetarian items like house-made knishes, potato pancakes and spinach logs will warm you up, too.

column7: Of the many Indian buffets dotting midtown, this colorful, predictably decorated eatery is a standout. While à la carte dinners are certainly an alluring (if pricey) option, the all-you-can-eat weekend buffet is a real steal—$14 per person, and kids eat for half price. It packs a spicy punch with (take a deep breath): one lamb and two chicken dishes (saucy curry and tender tandoori), four vegetable dishes, several appetizers, rice, fluffy nan and two desserts. The classic channa saag (creamed spinach with chickpeas) delivers authentic flavor and is always a favorite.

column7: The beloved East 10th Street institution’s new space, though lacking some of the charm of its old location, still recalls a Gallic countryside bistro—down to the pleasingly rustic menu. Slabs of croissant French toast resemble flaky elephant-ear pastry, and expertly poached eggs come with hollandaise and smoky chicken-and-apple sausage. Booths are up a flight of stairs, but the ramp into the first-floor dining room makes stroller navigation a breeze.

column7: The three Josie’s (the others are on the UWS and the UES) serve organic and vegetarian dishes that get their punch from sassy sauces: Pan-seared black-soybean dumplings come with miso-mango dip; a roasted half-chicken is perked up with a Thai sauce. Since such dishes may be a little exotic for younger palates, kids will probably be happier ordering simple cappellini with organic tomato sauce or an organic soy-cheese veggie burger.

column7: Though the pizza here isn’t fired in a brick or coal oven, the crust comes out beautifully charred. The pizzas are quaint: The small plain cheese pie is slathered with a deliciously zesty tomato sauce and covered with melted rounds of locally sourced fresh mozzarella and torn basil. You can also order pies half red and half white (with ricotta cheese), or choose from a variety of toppings. Nick’s overstuffed calzones are truly delicious, as are the cannoli; still, it’s the ’za that has made owner Nick Angelis a local hero.

column7: On Sunday mornings, packs of parents and kids head to this home-cooking haven, or its uptown sister, to partake of one of the top brunches in the city. There are many imaginative egg dishes, but your carb-loving tot can likely make a meal out of a fluffy, fist-sized biscuit with a dollop of strawberry butter. Kitchenette’s no disappointment at night, either: Try the honey-fried chicken or BBQ salmon.

column7: Should you wish to make soup the centerpiece of dinner rather than just a starter, look no further than Blue Ribbon’s swank Fifth Avenue outpost in Park Slope. It is exceedingly welcoming to families, even though it’s open evenings only (well, a 4pm weekend dinner could almost be called lunch). Among the great selection, our favorites include the spicy fish, filled with what seems like an ocean’s worth of protein; garlicky cream of tomato; and the famed matzo ball soup. None are cheap (ranging from around $7-$11), but portions are huge, and the list of eminently shareable raw-bar specials, appetizers and salads with which to expand your meal is enticing, to say the least. But before you fill up on extras, remember to focus on the soup–anything else will fit in a doggie bag.

column7: Welcome to Union Square’s slice of Americana—a huge slice. A jumble of antique cooking gear surrounds the enthusiastic diners who fill the farmhouse-kitchen tables at this longtime comfort-food haven. Plates of Uncle Red’s Addiction (honey-dipped fried chicken, which tastes candied) and the house best-seller, macaroni and cheese (covered with a crisp savory crust), are as delicious as they are generously apportioned. Unfortunately, the service can be uneven: On our most recent visit, the server was more interested in showing off quasi–-cheesy kung fu moves to the hostess than in bringing us our food.

column7: Just as it does at the original Gramercy-Flatiron location (99 E 19th St at Park Ave South, 212-260-2922), Duke’s in midtown serves one part pop-culture ephemera to two parts Southern comfort food. That means bright walls plastered with autographed photos, album covers and baseball cards, and big plasma-screen TVs tuned to sporting events. Heaps of Cajun-fried calamari, fried chicken with buttermilk gravy, catfish po’ boys and open-faced turkey sandwiches hit the spot.

column7: Got a yen for guacamole en molcajete—made in a volcanic-rock mortar and pestle—and a squish-happy kid? Head to one of Rosa Mexicano’s three outposts, where children can get a crash course plus a souvenir I ROCKED THE GUAC apron. There’s no charge for the five-minute session (although guac for two will set you back $14), and lessons are available anytime; but guac gurus might be inclined toward a more extensive one-on-one when they aren’t slammed. No word yet about whether they’ll teach your tots how to make killer margaritas.

column7: Charles Gabriel grew up cooking for his 19 siblings in North Carolina, so he knows from Southern cuisine. His Harlem kitchen launches a multilateral assault on the arteries, offering breakfast, fried seafood, takeout fare and an eat-in buffet. He whips up four specials a day—mostly soulful grub like panfried chicken, barbecued ribs, meaty oxtails, flash-fried whiting and pork chops smothered in peppery brown gravy. The decor isn’t all that special, but the fried chicken will make you forget your surroundings—it’s some of the best in the city, with tender, juicy meat and a crispy exterior. Raise a white flag when you’re full.

column7: Explore the various cuisines of Brooklyn without ever setting foot in the borough at this Times Square eatery (or its Carnegie Hall cohort), where the menu ricochets back and forth from red-sauce Italian to buttery noodle kugel to other old-world delicacies, all in ginormous portions. Where else are you going to see a so-called 15-bite all-beef hot dog served on a brioche bun with spicy mustard, sweet pickle relish, sauerkraut and onions rings for $15.95? If the menu doesn’t fascinate your little ones, the baseball-themed, wood-paneled space definitely will.

column7: Next time you’re strolling around Soho, stop by this longtime favorite, which maintains the same successful formula honed in the days when galleries (not chain stores) ruled the neighborhood. Owner Jerry Joseph mixes diner cool with ’80s artiness: red booths, a wall of Ralph Gibson and Starn Twins originals, and a black-clad waitstaff. Executive chef Eric Thomas, formerly of BLT Steak, serves comfort food with French bistro influences. Grilled portobello-mushroom pizza and piquant citrus-braised short ribs are popular with regulars, many of whom bring their kids (ages 8 and under eat free from the kids’ menu in early evening).

column7: Buffalorib eye and rattlesnake salad are among the ferocious fare on the pan-Euro menu at this white-tablecloth Brooklyn Heights standby. For a taste of the season, the wild-game menu dazzles with hearty dishes such as fragrant, oregano-encrusted elk chops. Year-roundwinners include a mustard-seed-crusted tuna served over spinach drizzled with soy and mustard oil.

column7: This diner is as much an East Village fixture as Tompkins Square Park, right across the street. The traditional diner fare--juicy hamburgers, grilled cheese and heaping nachos--is served in massive portions and at relatively reasonable prices. While the space isn’t exactly stroller-friendly, its casual atmosphere and affable service make this an inviting spot for a bite to eat after a session at Tompkins Playground.

column7: Round up a posse and head to this rodeo of a restaurant for tasty, festive Southwestern fare. Children can order corn dogs, quesadillas or catfish fingers from their own menu, and there are plenty of shareable options on the regular list of dishes. The popular Frito Pie, which consists of those famous corn chips covered in chili and cheese, is served in their namesake bag.

column7: Midtown’s Delta Grill offers solid Louisiana-style cooking in kitschy surroundings. Although a bit lighter than the usual stick-to-your-ribs recipe, the aromatic gumbo with tender pieces of chicken is a treat. Encourage young hot-dog lovers to sample the relatively mild red beans and rice, studded with andouille sausage. For dessert, try the syrupy cinnamon-raisin bread pudding, mammoth enough to satisfy a tableful of cravings.

column7: At this buzzing Italian institution, arriving early is a must if you want to avoid waiting around: Families crowd the cozy, casual and surprisingly inexpensive spot’s tables nightly. Although the menu features plenty of flavorful fish and meat entrées, kids tend to order the simple, hearty pastas such as homemade gnocchi with tomato, cream and basil or spaghetti with cherry-tomato marinara sauce. The generous desserts (primarily Italian traditions like a delectable tiramisu and a lighter panna cotta) can easily be shared.

column7: Mama’s Food Shop has long been a favorite of East Village hipsters on a budget, but it is also the perfect place to eat a home-cooked meal when you’re not up for spending time in front of the stove. After entertaining the dining room–which looks like the living room of an artsy aunt who knows how to make killer fried chicken–we sidled up to a counter laden with bowls of colorful and simply prepared vegetables like brussles sprouts, roasted carrots and string beans with garlic. I loved that we were able to create our own plates, choosing one portion of meat or fish–such as fried or roasted chicken, meat loaf or grilled salmon–and two sides for $10. You can also go all-vegetarian: For Belle, I balanced a pile of mac and cheese with a side of honey-glazed sweet potatoes and broccoli (portions are not kid-sized, but the leftovers make for a great next-day lunch), and we shared my order of crunchy, succulent fried chicken. The cafeteria-style service is a big plus: You can order immediately, grab a seat in the living-dinning room and eat at your own pace. The constant buzz of activity in the open kitchen provided all the entertainment Belle needed.

column7: Few mom-and-pop Arthur Avenue spots are as family-friendly as this joint, located in the heart of the borough’s Little Italy. Spacious enough for you to bring along the kids without guilt, Umberto’s offers a slew of options everyone loves, from golden mozzarella sticks to crispy fish-and-chips and, of course, more than a dozen pasta dishes including top-notch spaghetti or penne with homestyle red sauce.

column7: This vegetarian spot, like Candle Cafe a few blocks away, caters to people who are vigilant about what enters their bodies (even dishes containing casein and honey are clearly marked). For a delicious, if fiery, dish, try the sesame tofu nori roll served with a knock-your-socks-off wasabi dressing. Tamer types will wolf down the all-veggie lasagna, and little ones we know swear by the vanilla soy ice cream ($3 for one scoop).

column7: Every day, a fresh batch of peanut butter is shipped in to create mood pacifiers like the Elvis (peanut butter and banana with honey); the cinnamon-raisin-flavored peanut-butter sandwich, with vanilla cream cheese and tart apple slices; and the Heat Is On sandwich with spicy PB, grilled chicken and pineapple jam. Goober-free items continue the brown-bag theme—tuna melt, bologna sandwich...you get the idea.

column7: Many of us still lament the loss of the original Sacred Chow, the deli-style vegan eatery on Hudson Street in the west Village. But its reincarnation in the heart of NYU-dom greatly improves upon the original. A deep-red-painted brick wall, fanciful grape-bunch lights dangling throughout and a small Turkish fountain give the place a calm Eastern vibe. Table service, new tapas offerings, beers on tap and a host of organic wines all enhance what is truly excellent, inventive fare. Best of all, you’ll have no trouble recognizing the old Sacred Chow’s signature soups and stews by name or taste: the Vietnamese sweet-potato’s silken lightness and intense but soft flavors are still there, as is the dense richness of the black-bean chili soup. All the old favorites rotate as daily specials.

column7: Justly famous for its chewy, oversize cookies and rich hot chocolate, this beloved joint also offers healthy buffet options like organic mesclun greens with chianti vinaigrette (don’t worry, teetotalers: It’s alcohol-free). Picky toddlers wolf down delectable chicken wings and mac and cheese, both sold by the pound. Unless you dine off-hours, be prepared to duke it out for real estate.

column7: The décor at this mainstay hasn’t changed since the mid-1960s and is reminiscent of a school cafeteria—as are the long lines. The attraction is inexpensive seafood and shameless deep-fat frying: fillet of sole, red snapper, whiting, smelts, mini lobster tails, shrimp, scallops, soft-shell crabs, clams, oysters and squid. The clam bar, meanwhile, offers shucked-before-your-eyes littlenecks and cherrystones for $10 a dozen.

column7: This elegant townhouse restaurant opened in 1906 as a hangout for Broadway bigwigs and is still popular among the theater crowd. The setting—gilded chandeliers and ornate furniture— is fittingly dramatic, as is the Piedmontese menu. Dishes such as diver scallops in a sweet tomato jus and rabbit, roasted and lavished with a lemony wine sauce, are best enjoyed in the back garden, an unlikely retreat in bustling Hell’s Kitchen.

column7: Founders Ben Hoen and Matt Pisciotta’s neighborhood diner is perpetually lively and family-packed: Little ones clamor for Mini Mees (tiny versions of sirloin, turkey or veggie burgers), Peter au Pain (French toast stuffed with Nutella) and Rice Krispies–topped mac and cheese. Grown-ups shouldn’t miss the delicious Ben-a-Dizz, a kickier take on eggs Benedict. Be prepared to stand in line Sunday mornings.

column7: This offshootof Norma Jean Darden’s original Morningside Heights restaurant doesn’t have tour buses parked out front like Sylvia’s does—and the food is better. Get a plateful of short ribs, flaky cornmeal-crusted catfish or rich-and-savory fried chicken you’ll dream about for weeks to come. On weekends, the brunch menu includes kid-friendly favorites like pecan waffles and buttermilk biscuits. If you’re closer to West 110th Street, head to Spoonbread’s sister, Miss Mamie’s (366 W 110th St between Manhattan and Columbus Aves, 212-865-6744) instead.

column7: Shabu Shabu 70, open since the Nixon administration, is a hidden gem on the Upper East Side. On a Sunday night we sat at a banquette in the front room, next to the bar (with a good view of the TV), and watched as a constant flow of regulars, including families with kids, came in and were greeted personally by the hostess and waitstaff. The sushi and Japanese specialties, like crab shumai and Japanese pickles, are well made and fresh, but we came for the fireworks known as the hot pot. For shabu-shabu, a cast-iron pot is filled with broth made from water, sake and seaweed, then placed on a burner at your table. The waiters bring you raw meat sliced so thin that it will cook in mere seconds, as well as a bowl of raw vegetables, silky udon noodles and two dipping sauces. For novices, the friendly waiters (who all sport shaggy mohawks) will get you started and provide instruction. Letting very young children take a turn at the pot is not recommended, but Belle was held rapt by our routine of dunking the ingredients and fishing them out. She also enjoyed the results, including the chance to dip her noodles and chicken into the sauces herself. Although a bit on the pricey side ($25 per person with a two-person minimum), two shabu-shabu orders can feed several people.

column7: A beloved shawarma stop for Carroll Gardens and Cobble Hill families since 1998, Zaytoons serves Syrian, Lebanese and Palestinian dishes. We like the fattoush salad ($4) and malphouf ($10), a Syrian stuffed cabbage filled with rice, beef and a hint of cinnamon. Other highlights include a spicy falafel and pillowy, baked-to-order pitas, perfect for scooping up hummus and tabouli. Walls hand-painted to resemble the thick bricks and archways of a Middle Eastern coffeehouse enhance the cozy atmosphere.

column7: Ravenous? We’ve got just the place. Chef-owner Carrie Levin’s nostalgic dishes, based on family recipes, are served in grizzly-bear portions. Brunchers pack the farmhouse-style space for fluffy eggs and plump buttermilk biscuits with chili. If home cooking were really this good, we’d still be living with Mom and Dad.

column7: This old pooch’s newest trick: The owners of the cozy West Village institution of the same name offer a similar menu and family-friendly vibe in this eastern outpost. That means a selection of hearty sandwiches, burgers and salads for lunch and dinner, and the always-popular traditional brekkie options. The decor may be a bit more ambitious here than at the Carmine Street location (owners David Ethan and Peter Stein scoured antiques markets for the perfect accent pieces), but it’s still laid-back. Get your tykes there before 9:30am on Saturdays and Sundays to avoid the rush, and fill up on brunch standards like challah French toast.

column7: If you’re prowling around Murray Hill, perhaps en route to the Kips Bay movie theater for the latest Pixar flick, stop by unpretentious Ali Baba. The eatery is best known for its doner ($12) and beyti ($12.50) kebabs and ezme, a fiery tomato salad ($5.50), but we prefer the simple dishes: perfectly blended red lentil soup ($4) squeezed with lemon; and the cacik ($5.25), a garlicky cucumber-and-yogurt sauce. Kids will likely go for the chicken kebab with french fries ($12.95) and the crisp, cinnamon-flavored baklava ($4.50). Avoid the weekend dinner rush by making a reservation or arriving extra early.

column7: Sleek looks, spacious seating and a turbocharged waitstaff set Lili’s apart from the rest of the noodle shop bunch. You can slurp from big bowls of soup here, but what really beckon are the oversize platters of seafood, like grilled shrimp kebabs with Lili’s “special sauce.” Steer skeptical tots toward the Americanized standards—crispy egg rolls, heaping portions of lo mein—also available at the mini-chain’s other locations (200 W 57th St at Sixth Ave, 212-586-5333; 102 North End Ave at Vesey St, 212-786-1300).

column7: The sight of “monkey gland” sauce ($3) on the menu at I-Shebeen Madiba brings out a certain anxiety in young diners. What kind of gland? Is that even legal? Fret not: Here in Fort Greene, the sweet-and-sour sauce is made the old South African way, with chutney, butter, ketchup, Tabasco and a dash of port wine. Alas, no monkey ingredients, although it does come with a large beefsteak. Herbivores might prefer the Durban Bunny Chow, a hearty bowl of stew made with ingredients bunnies enjoy, served in a hollowed-out loaf of bread.

column7: A classic railway diner is the last thing you’d expect to find in the industrial canyons of Tribeca, but the Square Diner is no mirage, and neither are its old-fashioned prices. Ply your family with standard diner food—burgers, sandwiches, salads—and Greek dishes like souvlaki. Kids (and grown-ups) can indulge in a thick milk shake or root beer float. Be warned: The early-rising staff give themselves a well-deserved break on weekends, when they close shop at 4pm.

column7: Stepping into this Philippe Starck–designed restaurant is like going to a tea party with the Mad Hatter: The high-ceilinged dining room is outfitted with long communal tables and high-backed chairs that resemble chess pieces. The seasonal menu is all over the map—Asian, American—but kids go for the haute comfort items like gooey mac and cheese (optionally topped with roasted chicken breast or portobello mushrooms). A finely spiced slab of meat loaf conceals a pocket of melted cheddar, and the chicken noodle soup is perfectly homey, loaded with white meat, pastina, carrots and fresh herbs.

column7: When 3 o’clock rolls around, neighborhood kids gather here for after-school snacks like oatmeal-chocolate cookies. Earlier in the day, when the café is popular with the stroller set, toddlers tuck into PB&J muffins. After 5pm, the cozy, brightly colored space shifts gears yet again, offering entrées like mac and cheese, enchiladas and burgers.

column7: You’ve possibly never said, “Let’s have British food tonight,” but a trip to this chippy—one of the few in Manhattan—might change that. The place serves freshly fried, vinegar-doused whiting, haddock and sole with sides of better-than-french-fries “chips.” Kids who love fish sticks can try finger-size fried “fish bites”; fish sandwiches served with tartar sauce are also available. With only eleven stools, dining indoors here is near impossible, so you might want to take your order to go or nosh while seated on the bench outside.

column7: For the ultimate cup o’ noodles, park your tyke on one of the 14 stools at cozy Tokyo-style ramen bar Rai Rai Ken, where the glistening bowl of shoyu ramen ($7) reigns supreme. The soy-based broth is graced with superlative versions of the usual suspects—tender slices of pork, fresh spinach, bamboo shoots, boiled egg, fish cake, scallions and nori, plus those glorious long noodles, cooked until ha gotai (think al dente, but in Japanese).

column7: Is there anything this restaurant can’t batter? The fish-and-chips here and at the shop’s other location (129 Atlantic Ave between Clinton and Henry Sts, Cobble Hill) are among New York’s best, whether you choose cod, haddock or plaice. This is also the spot for such U.K. classics as bangers and mash, Welsh rarebit and shepherd’s pie. And for dessert, go for one of their famous deep-fried candy bars. The Monday–Thursday special (20% off the eat-in menu from 4:30 to 6:30pm) is a perk for the early-bedtime crowd.

column7: Elegant and snug, this Williamsburg bistro doesn’t flaunt its G rating. But that’s why parents love coming here: Kids’ needs are seen to quickly and patiently, yet grown-ups are the center of attention. Chase one of the rich pasta or fish specials with a soothing sidecar cocktail, while your younger dining companions split a helping of the DuMac and Cheeseor a moist and messy burger.

column7: Danny Meyer may be the king of high-end American fare, but he’s still a Missouri boy at heart. Choose from Kansas City spareribs, Texas-style salt ’n’ pepper ribs and Memphis-style baby back ribs. The standout children’s menu includes fired-up favorites like the ribs in addition to more traditional kid fare (mac and cheese, for instance), plus fried or mashed, salad or vegetable, a drink and ice cream.

column7: Rely on this low-key joint for affordable Asian-inspired grub. Scallion pancakes with mango salsa and tofu-skin wraps generously packed with veggies make easy finger-food treats. Hunks of soy in an almond-laced, sweet citrus sauce atop crispy kale is a lighter alternative to General Tso’s chicken. Treat the kids to an after-dinner mojito—sans rum, of course.

column7: Tackling an iron platter of sizzling meat at this LES Argentine eatery requires some vigor. Prime yourself with exquisitely flaky empanadas nestling a hearty beef-and-olive filling. Then go for the earthy skirt steak—red as a plum inside and singing with garlicky chimichurri sauce. The low-lit, brick-and-wood bistro may appear urban when compared with the rustic grill houses of Buenos Aires, but the waiters, transfixed by the televised futbol at the tiny bar, are textbook porteño.

column7: After the success of Frank, on Second Avenue, Frank Prisinzano opened this smaller, pizza-oriented offshoot with a garden out back. None of his enterprises stay small for long, and this one, which expanded into the next-door space, is no different. Neighborhood regulars (and their expanding families) swarm in to enjoy the thin-crust, wood-oven-baked personal pies. The Classic Margharita is lavishly sauced, while the cheeseless Bianca is liberally brushed with truffle oil and flecked with rosemary.

column7: Beloved by brides-to-be and Disney-adoring children, this magical spot offers much more than $9 pots of tea. The brunch menu is fit for royalty, with Alice’s Curious French Toast (it’s drenched in fruit coulis, vanilla crème anglaise and syrup) and scones in scrumptious flavors like blueberry and pumpkin. Special occasion? Outfit your fairy-princess-in-training with a pair of glittery wings, available for purchase at the store’s gift shop. And don’t worry if there’s a line. Alice’s has an interior waiting area with reading material for parents and assorted furry figures, including a grinning Cheshire cat, for kids to play with.

column7: The best way to get your kids to eat their greens is not to offer them a deceptively delicious browie, but rather to ply them with a plate of luscious noodles accented by a gorgeous vegetable. Pam Real Tahi Food’s pad see ew (called pad see eil on the menu; $6.50) is just the ticket—marvelous flat, broad rice noodles, leafy and crunchy Chinese broccoli, thinly sliced beef and soft egg curds in a neatly balanced, sweet soy-based sauce.

column7: True, Otto’s train station–themed name board (you get your table when your “city” comes up) will inspire eye-rolling—as will the lengthy wait if you fail to make a reservation. The Otto team can get away with it, though, because the food lives up to its rep. Italian cheeses come with such condiments as apricot mostarda or black-truffle honey. The weakest link might be the restaurant’s centerpiece, the individual-sized pizzas. Toppings are terrific, but the crust can be a bit limp. Still, at about $13 a pie and with everything else so perfect, it’s hard to complain.

column7: Put your hungry family in the capable hands of Roberto Paciullo, a Salerno native who runs this no-frills eatery. Grab a seat at one of the wooden tables and let Paciullo create a proper four-course feast. For kids, a baked tinfoil plate of tiny radiator-shaped pasta comes bathed in a vibrant red sauce; parents can dive into short ribs spiked with a rich chili-pepper-and-beer sauce. Let your meal be the centerpiece of a field trip to one of the city’s few remaining authentic Italian-American neighborhoods.

column7: You won’t find much candy for sale here. Instead you’ll discover a wonderfully preserved diner dating back to 1925, its long counter lined with chatty locals on their lunch hours digging into perfectly grilled tuna melts and delish peanut-butter-and-bacon sandwiches, and sipping freshly squeezed lemonade that strikes just the right balance between tart and sweet. Two nits to pick, though: The overhyped milk shakes are too thin and the bathrooms are, frankly, gross.

column7: Australia may be the only nation as fond of supersizing as ours. So it’s no wonder that Down Under eatery Sunburnt Cow’s hefty burger ($9) is so tall it’s probably easier to attack sideways. They do things differently down there, so along with lettuce, tomato and cheese, this whopper is piled with bacon, fried egg, beet, and pineapple–a.k.a. “the Lot”–and thus tastes like a cross between a meat loaf and a tropical salad. For those with an aversion to that description, try the Bangers and Smash (mashed potatoes served with kangaroo sausage).

column7: Crowds of in-the-know locals and a cozy, rustic interior (complete with exposed brick, candlelight and wooden tables) promise a satisfying, old-fashioned dining experience, and with its soul-pleasing menu of classic pasta dishes and well-executed entrées, Brick doesn’t disappoint. The same holds true for brunch, when the restaurant not only cooks up some of the fluffiest omelettes in town but also pulls textbook lattes strong enough to rouse even the most sleep-deprived parents.

column7: Nazareth native Rawia Bishara has created something magical at her bright Bay Ridge storefront. Pay special attention to dishes centering on eggplant (at its peak through early fall) and lamb: We were floored by the shushbarak ($18), lamb ravioli cooked in a mint-garlic-yogurt sauce and served with vermicelli and rice ($18), and the eggplant napoleon ($6.50), baba ghanoush sandwiched between tender crisp-fried aubergine disks and topped with chopped tomato-basil salad. The secret to Bishara’s cooking lies in imported, fresh ground spices, which she sprinkles over her dishes with a doting mother’s care.

column7: Plenty of children tag along to this upscale “diner” to nosh on panisse (chickpea fries with aioli) and whole-wheat penne from the kids’ menu. More precocious palates will be rewarded with adult fare like potato-almond gnocchi in a tangy, lemony thyme sauce, or the Italian farmhouse panini slathered with walnut-lentil pâté. For dessert, order the pecan sundae with gooey hot fudge for the kids, and an organic tarragon-infused vodka martini for yourself.

column7: The foodies who flock to Sripraphai would say coming here for pad thai is like going to Nobu for tekka maki. Let ’em—great is great. The dish (7.50) is strikingly fresh, full of flavor, and the essence of what this kid favorite should be. Chewy rice noodles, substantial shrimp that are actually worth sinking your teeth into, matchsticks of tofu, scrambles of egg and the requisite bean sprout-peanut-lime wedge combo are brought together in the four-part harmony of spicy, sweet, salty and sour that makes authentic Thai cuisine a thrill.

column7: Don’t be intimidated by the spiral-bound, ten-page menu at this homey-looking Astoria treasure; we’ll give you the delicious highlights. Start with the halloumi ($7.50), hearty sheep-and-goat’s-milk cheese that’s grilled and served with lemon; or sheftalia ($8), pork meatballs studded with green onions and herbs. The innovative children’s menu includes pork kebab with Cypriot fries ($9). Though it won’t be easy, save roomfor the shamali ($4), a honey-soaked semolina cake perfumed with cloves, cinnamon and rose water.

column7: By night, Landmarc is the perfect mommy-and-daddy destination featuring elegant interiors, robust dishes and a kilelr wine list. By day, however, it’s very kid-friendly, with wipeable wood tables, a kids’ menu and several types of juice by the glass. While children have lots of choices, ranging from veggie sticks with peanut butter to a bowl of Cheerios, those with more adult tastes get the most out of their meals. Chef Marc Murphy’s menu offers bistro favorites like frisée aux lardons, duck confit, and moules frites. Daytime fare is a bit lighter, and includes traditional sandwiches like croque-monsieurs and pain bagnat. No matter what time you go, dessert is a must.

column7: If your tot wants to try a dish that sounds like it’s straight out of a first-grade dare, head to Public, where they combine braised oxtail and snail meat into ravioli–big, hot, floppy pockets of ground-up gastropod ($23). They’re slightly salty, with a bit of a chew, but pretty darn tasty nonetheless. That’s not the only dish here that’ll provide your kid with bragging rights: Have her try the deep-fried quail egg that comes with coconut-infused laksa (noodle soup) or the panna cotta with a knock-your-socks-off lime-wasabi jelly.

column7: Make-your-own-pizza parties have been a big hit here since Pinch’s 2003 opening. Each kid gets a section of a three-foot-long pie to decorate, choosing from a list of 25 toppings. Children can take the traditional route, simply using pepperoni, for instance—or be mad scientists, piling on spinach, sweet sausage and roasted garlic. At party time or dinnertime, Pinch believes in freedom of choice. In fact, you can order your pie in lengths of 4, 12 or 36 inches, with a different topping every four inches.

column7: If you have children, or just want to act like one, come to this part-diner, part-arcade. The long gray counter is decorated with, among other colorful tchotchkes, a Homer Simpson figurine. Kids—and their parents—will appreciate old-school video games like Pac-Man and Galaga. And as cartoons play on plasma TVs above the counter, happy patrons can order a thick-and-creamy malted, a hot dog or a hot fudge sundae. Mmm...rainbow sprinkles.

column7: If you like your pork ribs smoked-rubbed, head to this biker joint on Harlem’s far west side. Call ahead to reserve a table, or be prepared for up to a two-hour wait (always fun with little ones). On a typical Saturday night, the front sidewalk is crowded with hungry patrons and rows of Harleys. In addition to killer versions of ribs and pulled pork, Dinosaur offers superior sides, like delicate fried green tomatoes and Syracuse salt potatoes (boiled, then sauced with garlic and butter). Bonus points for the temporary T. rex tattoos offered to the whole family.

column7: At this better-than-fast-food joint, juicy Angus beef patties come on a brioche bun, either unadorned or fully loaded (try the Chicago, topped with cherrywood-smoked bacon, Cabot cheddar and homemade Thousand Island dressing). Extras include salads, crispy onion rings and refreshing smoothies like the Berry Extreme, a zingy combo of strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, cranberry and orange juices, and vanilla ice cream. A second location sits a bit to the west (678 Sixth Ave between 21st and 22nd Sts; 212-229-1404).

column7: If the menu at R.U.B. (Righteous Urban Barbecue) seems unusually authentic, there’s a reason why: Paul Kirk, a Kansas City legend who’s won hundreds of awards and authored several books on smoking and grilling, designed all the recipes and menu contents. The result is pure pig heaven. Head chef Scott Smith slow-smokes pastrami for 14 hours and serves “burnt ends”—brisket that’s smoked twice and cooked well-done. Bonus: They serve a daily cobbler. You’ll have a hard time getting the kids out of here with clean faces.

column163: POP Diner80-26 Queens Blvd at 51st Ave, Elmhurst, Queens (718-426-2229)Subway: G, V, R to Grand Ave–NewtownSun-Thu 7am-1am; Fri, Sat 24 hoursCredit cards: AmEx, MC, VTakeout, delivery, cateringFull barAverage main course: $14H/c access to restaurant, yes; h/c stallsAmericanElmhurst, Queenswww.popdiner.com(147 words)In the foodie mecca that is Queens, even a diner can knock your bib off. Friendly, Fifties-chandeliered POP Diner features the usual breakfasts, burgers, sundaes and midnight espressos. But unlike most diners, it takes its food seriously, confidently turning out generous, creative dishes. Seafood is a particular strength, accounting for tender fried calamari and meaty Maryland crabcakes. Seafood risotto, bursting with fresh, saffron-kissed squid and shellfish, is as expertly cooked as a fancy paella. And on a recent visit a savory T-bone steak arrived rare as requested, a rare occurrence. Quality touches are everywhere—house-baked challah rolls, daquiris made with fresh berries, entrée-accompanying soups as thick as stews. And, for once in a diner, the homemade desserts taste as good as they look. (The cheesecake tastes even better.) POP Diner does many things well, but it’s best at making you think you’re dining in a fine restaurant.

column163: Curry Row should be afraid. Very afraid. Because once people get a taste of Angon, no one’s going to settle for what the other places have to offer. The wonders begin the minute you step inside. Not a tacky garish chili-pepper light anywhere. Milton TK, a host and co-owner, is an attentive, gregarious water-filler; the only thing more sparkling than his vest is his smile. The star is the chef: Mina TK, who Milton claims is the first female chef among the Indian restaurants on 6th Street, has quite the cult following. On one visit, we discovered several diners were fans who had followed the Chowhound darling from Mina’s Foods in Queens to this location. And for good reason. There is virtually no flat dish on the menu. Aloo tikka (deep-fried potato balls) has a remarkably even breading and an unusually rich creaminess. Samosa chat was virtually unrecognizable, covered in a yogurt sauce packed with more herbs and flavors than we could ever guess at. The caramelized onions on top of the khichuri (lentil and rice) made the dish a tad sweet but it all became a nice foil for the spicy chicken curry on the side. Dal fry, the house specialty of fried and baked lentils, was truly spectacular and complexly flavored, though you wouldn’t have known by the way one server described it: It’s just some lentils with turmeric, onion, garlic, ginger and cilantro. There are probably some secret ingredients he left out. No matter. We’ll just enjoy Mina’s magic touch—and pity the other restaurants.

column7: David and Laura Shea’s charming eatery has country-cozy decor, organic produce and a kid-friendly vibe—three things that make city parents happy. Tables are adorned with bundled fresh herbs, and many ingredients come from local and Vermont farms. What you might find on the menu (it changes daily): ricotta dumplings with braised pork shoulder, a bacon-and-delicata-squash omelette and wild striped bass with curried mussel chowder. Brunch brings goodies like brioche French toast and a side of thick-cut bacon—and kids’-menu prices that are (surprisingly) much lower than your average diner’s.

column163: There’s more on the menu than varietals at this Williamsburg wine bar. Tucked on a quiet side street, this cozy and unpretentious spot charms with brown-paper covered tables and menus held together with wooden spoons. To satisfy any hunger that might develop while working through the impressive list of 70 Italian wines—with nightly vino specials added—D.O.C also serves up a host of palate-pleasing small plates, all perfect for sharing. A mouthwatering assortment of cheeses can be ordered individually and also come in cheese and cold cut platters. The vegetarian carpaccio is served as a heaping mound of thin, perfectly rolled slices of carrot and zucchini topped with a generous dose of parmesan shavings. An assortment of pistokku—traditional flatbread from the region of Sardinia—are served pizza style, warm and crispy with toppings such as bresaola (air cured beef), goat cheese and argula. The only disappointment of the evening was a mealy fregola pasta with proscuitto and a bland gorgonzola cream sauce, but that was quickly overshadowed by a ricotta mousse with chocolate chips and fresh strawberries. And, of course, another glass of wine.

column93: J.J.’s Fusion Kitchen and Sushi Bar
column144: Subway: N, R to 30th Ave
column163: This seductively low-lit, house-music-playing Astoria spot is not your average neighborhood sushi bar. “Asian fusion” explains a lot, including the union of owner J.J., who’s Indonesian and New Zealander, and her Shanghai-born husband, chef Richard Lin. “Asian fusion” also describes their menu of familiar, mostly-Japanese dishes recreated with tropical accents. Thai-style shredded duck salad goes nicely sweet and sour with jicama and citrusy yuzu sauce, and sushi is sparked with unexpected tastes like mango and jalapeño. Richard’s “white pepper tuna” sushi, a smoky yellowtail, is not to be missed, and chili-spiced, barely seared tuna pleases as an entrée. “Fusion” is often a coverup for watered-down Asian food, but J.J.’s has nothing to hide.

column7: Get over hating Whole Foods, because this chain simply has one of the city’s best buffets. Your family may have to scramble for a seat, especially at the packed Columbus Circle location, but $7.99/pound lets you sample literally dozens of globally inspired dishes. The steamed kale is piquant and brilliant green, and there’s no better place to introduce children to unusual grains (wheat berries, quinoa, kasha). Constant crowds ensure that the food is replenished frequently, so your lasagna never has the dry edges that plaque 24-hour deli bars.

column7: Even if your children are too young to admire the goth decor at this popular neighborhood joint, they’ll appreciate the chow. Favorites include potatoes Parmesan ($7), Spanish tortillas ($6 each) and—for a nice break from typical mozzarella sticks—fried breaded Manchego ($8). The most indulgent dishes are the desserts: grilled baby bananas and homemade pistachio ice cream, or build-your-own s’mores ($6 each).

column7: Among the faded storefronts on Amsterdam Avenue, this spot boldly announces itself, courtesy of its blue neon sign. But it also attracts attention for the namesake flatbread wraps that dominate its small menu. Similar to kathi rolls (kebab-stuffed Indian bread), these savory frankies are filled with ingredients like spiced egg, chicken and lamb and are topped with yogurt-and-cilantro sauce. You can get them to go, but the potato-filled ones feel like they weigh seven pounds each, so eat them at the counter if you’ve got kids in tow.

column7: How could a place called Picket Fence be anything other than cheerful and family-welcoming? The restaurant delivers the “comfortable food” it promises and an atmosphere to match. Service is relaxed but attentive, accompanied by music from the likes of the Beatles and the Police. Adults can savor a sublime dish of scallops and polenta cakes, accented with roasted bell peppers and garlic, while the little ones are appeased by the well-stocked kids’ menu—and a fine selection of toys and books.

column7: Yes, Telepan is a fancy, expensive restaurant. But it’s also on the Upper West Side, and thusly is equipped to handle children. Chef Bill Telepan (JUdson Grill, Bar Americain) mixes high-end ingredients with low-end recipes and vice versa. Whether high or low, the quality of Telepan’s ingredients and power of his culinary imagination is exceptional. Case in point: The killer carrot-cake sundae features cream-cheese ice cream and sugar-sweet Day-Glo carrot shavings. Although the place is upscale, the vibe is casual, and the servers are good-natured and knowledgeable. It feels like a friend’s apartment—filled with a bunch of Upper West Side moms and dads—only this friend can cook.

column7: When the Japanese cream-puff franchises moved in, we knew it was only a matter of time before the grill-it-yourself megachain Gyu-Kaku turned up, too. Here and at the midtown location (805 Third Ave at 50th St; 212-702-8816), meat lovers savor yakiniku standards, including kalbi (short ribs) and harami miso (skirt steak), along with more esoteric cuts like bite-size kobe kalbi. There’s even a way to get your kids to eat their greens: A platter of foil-encased vegetables is like a tray of little gifts waiting to be unwrapped.

column7: This Latin-influenced bakery sells heaven in a bun. Kids beeline for the signature offering: sweet, brioche-like bread filled with a choice of dulce de leche, Nutella or guava. But there’s also a savory version—a dense, fist-size ball made with yuca flour, along with beef and chicken empanadas and delicious little corn cakes. If the kids want something familiar, the grilled sandwiches (“booty-press specials”) come with a choice of guava jelly or banana and Fluff, pressed between thick slices of bread.

column7: The Philly cheese-steak craze isn’t ending anytime soon, and Ziggiz looks like it’s here for the long haul. Purists beware: At Ziggiz, the cheese steaks are automatically made with provolone, so you have to specify Whiz if you want an authentic Philly version. Otherwise, the sandwich sticks to the rules, with top-notch Angus and buns shipped in from Atlantic City. Brothers George and Steve Zamfotis, who also run a casual lunch spot, have hedged their bets by stocking the menu with kid-friendly burgers and burritos.

column7: The last time you toured Italy, your bambino was just a zygote. Relive the culinary highlights at this stylish yet casual Upper West Side spot, where your honeymoon baby can snooze in his stroller right by your table in the double-wide aisle. Each of Italy’s 20 regions is represented by at least one dish on the menu of small plates, pastas and entrées. Expect thick meat ragù, spicy fish stew, and classics like cavatelli with broccoli rabe, sweet sausage and dried chili. Toddlers will delight in the exotic-sounding cjalzun ampezzani: beet-and-ricotta ravioli in a simple thyme-butter sauce. The creamy beet filling is not only high in folate but also a lovely shade of hot pink. The management may hate us for saying so, but with its easygoing staff, cry-cloaking noise level and good selection of Italian wines by the glass, Regional is a parent’s dream.—Maureen Shelly

column7: No fancy amenities like table service here; instead, patrons cart their fare to one of the long picnic tables in the sunlit back room. The award-winning Sweet & Sticky Pork Ribs are a four-napkin affair and live up to the hype, delivering tender meat that practically falls off the bone. The price is also right—$17.50 buys six ribs and two side dishes. The red velvet cupcakes are a down-home treat not to be resisted; or skip dessert and satisfy your sweet tooth over dinner with the sweet potatoes with brown sugar and bananas.

column7: Javier Garcia’s Hell’s Kitchen shop tied for “Best cheap eats” in a vote by Time Out Kids readers. Like its sibling branches in Queens (named Mama’s Empanadas; see mamasempanadas.com for locations), the eatery peddles more than 40 varieties of the main attraction, perfectly sized for little hands. Fillings range from basic (plain cheese, or riceand beans) to ultracreative (ham, cheese and pineapple) and sweetly addictive (banana and Belgian chocolate, or figs, caramel and cheese).

column7: This stylish diner is beloved both for its kitschy charm and fusion comfort foods. The eclectic menu lists American favorites like burgers and grilled cheese sandwiches, as well as addictive Thai dishes like Massaman curry. Get the party started with vegetable dumplings served in their own steamer, accompanied by a sprightly chili-spiked soy sauce. Entrées, like juicy fried chicken with smashed potatoes, are superb, as are the decadent, down-home dessert classics.

column7: If your little ones can’t finish an entire burger, bring them to this Meatpacking District joint or its newer midtown sibling (14 E 58th between Fifth and Madison; 212-991-6644), adored for the mini burgers. Patties are made to order and come two to a box ($6, or three for $15 in the lounge), with a dollop of Russian dressing, shredded lettuce and a square of good old American cheese, served on a homemade brioche bun. Thick shakes and scrumptious cupcakes round out the kiddie-cool cuisine options.

column7: In your face, White Castle: Sassy’s serves five mini-patties (beef, turkey, veggie, barbecued chicken or chicken Parmesan) with toppings like browned onions and pickles. They’re only $1.09 each, but add another 12 for cheese and 79 for an extra patty. The milk shakes aren’t miniature (thank goodness), and killer flavors include a black-and-white malt and a decadent Coffee Heath Bar Crunch.

column7: Mo Pitkin’s “Judeo-Latino” cuisine is not too hip for you—or your tot. Kids will flock to the deep-fried mac and cheese, Coney Island–cut french fries and buttery potato latkes with homemade applesauce. If you’d like to expand their palates, consider a tray of Mo’s Pickin’s: A three-year-old, who normally won’t eat anything that isn’t breaded and fried, went crazy for a piquant escabeche and spicy chorizo meatballs. Top it all off with the best bread pudding in town.

Other dishes include West Indian staples like saltfish and aloo pie, a hearty Trinidadian pastry filled with curried potatoes.

column7: Craig Bero, the guy who brought us the faux-vintage candy store Be-Speckled Trout, opened this turn-of-the-20th-century-style parlor to pay homage to his fave childhood treat: ice cream. The shop features a white marble bar and fountain heads salvaged from the former creamery inside the Plaza Hotel. Kids love to dive into frothy favorites like the shop’s signature frothyfresh blueberry milk shakes and egg creams. And what could be better to pair with your meal than throwback bottled sodas like grape Squeeze and orange creamsicle?

column7: Comfort food goes high-concept at this Nolita eatery, but your kids won’t be intimidated—thanks to an inviting atmosphere and friendly service, they’ll probably even feel right at home. Meat loaf, fried chicken and PB&J all make an appearance on the menu, and many old-fashioned dishes get a playful, modern update. Mac and cheese, available as an appetizer, looks like an order of spring rolls: The creamy favorite has been rolled in a wonton wrapper, deep-fried and cut into bite-size portions. For dessert, peanut-butter ice cream is complemented by a delectable jelly sauce and brioche French toast.

column7: As advertised, everything at both the original and the second location (1596 Second Ave at 83rd St; 212-717-2020) is enormous—from the larger-than-life neon sign above the door to the heaping portions of amped-up diner fare, like Hunka Hunka Burnin’ Love Pancakes (studded with banana and chocolate chips) and mac and cheese. Don’t be shy about sliding a booster seat into your vinyl booth—the loud music, vast collection of vintage cereal boxes, and mural that’s chockablock with Tony the Tiger and Pac-Man icons make the place ultra-kid-friendly. Though Big Daddy is no cheap date (a cup of coffee alone will set parents back $2.50), the honey-dipped fried chicken has folks lining up on weekends.

column7: Since opening its doors in 2005, this joint has become a hit with Main Street’s young’uns who like their burgers and fries served straight up, with no plastic toys. Joe’s marries a classic fast-food menu familiar to anyone who’s made a pit stop on I-95 with a teen-centric atmosphere (plasma-screen TVs hang on the walls; XM Satellite radio pumps in tunes). And unlike that roadside Hardee’s, Joe’s cooks each order fresh. The burgers are topped with crisp lettuce, tomatoes with actual flavor (!), Joe’s special Thousand Island–esque sauce, and (if you like) grilled or raw onions.Click here

column7: Celebrity chef David Burke now serves oddball takeout grub—chicken dumplings with coffee barbecue sauce, spicy potato-chip pizza and cheeseburger sliders—in an equally unexpected location, the ground floor of Bloomingdale’s. At Burke Bar Café, the more elegant spot across the way, he offers breakfast, lunch and a $30 prix-fixe evening menu. At the bar, sample his famous cheesecake lollipops (though beware, they melt quickly) or any of Burke’s 18 flavored (calorie-free) sprays; they’re available as condiments, or you can take a bottle home for $4.50. Don’t go there for the ambiance, though: the bar has all the charm and personality of an Au Bon Pain.

column7: Most Malaysian restaurants have wisely chosen to call their loh shee fun “pearl noodles” rather than the traditional “rat’s tails,” but either way, wee ones can’t gobble them up fast enough. Sentosa’s clay pot of delicate pearl noodles ($6) brims with diced shrimp, scallops, squid, baby corn and more, in a generous swirl of those irresistible chewy, fat noodles.

column7: You don’t get much more infant-friendly than Perch Café. Built-in banquettes and sleek sofas are roomy enough for the whole family, and there’s plenty of space for the stroller, including, during warmer months, in the well-designed garden out back. Patrons love the chili-crusted shrimp over grits, the baked rosemary chicken and the hunk of love that is the red velvet cake. Your kids will also relish frequent sing-along concerts by adored local musicians.

column7: This café and lounge, located on an increasingly trendy block, delivers reliable, homestyle Italian food. Francine DiTomaso (Luca Lounge) and her husband, James Powers, have created boho ambience with antique-style metal fans and a soundtrack of sultry French pop. The menu is filled with solidly executed, generously portioned dishes, most of which are available in half sizes for kids. Sidewalk seating offers a prime view of the developing neighborhood.

column7: The owner of this incarnation of Casanis stole the name and the chef (Sebastian Maczko) from the old Casanis, which used to sit where Prune now does. Though the entrées are not jaw-droppingly creative, the eatery has become popular with families who like the casual atmosphere and reasonable prices.

column7: The decor—chandeliers made from Corona bottles and walls painted green, yellow and orange—says “Fiesta!” The menu features traditional Mexican fare and a few specialty dishes, like pozole (a white hominy stew) and chilaquiles (a homemade corn-tortilla casserole), native to southern Mexico, where executive chef Jorge Pareja was born and raised. Tried-and-true offerings—tacos, burritos, enchiladas, fajitas and so on—are all solid: We loved a quesadilla with fat chunks of shrimp and melted Monterey Jack. The music is loud—a blessing for parents—but the space is cramped. They don’t take reservations, so be prepared for a wait.

column7: This superb Pan-Asian noodle house is a welcome addition to the St. Marks Place cheap-eats canon. Treat your kids to a free show and sit by the glass-enclosed kitchen, where you can see chefs furiously sautéing and frying. The menu explains whether a particular item hails from Hong Kong, Malaysia, Thailand, China, Indonesia or Japan. We were smitten with the “Silver Needles”—an $11.75 plate of short, thick and slightly chewy noodles panfried with shredded pork and chicken, baby shrimp, bean sprouts, egg, and slivers of carrot and onion.

column7: This 10,000-square-foot space is full of quirky aquatic touches that keep kids distracted, such as oversize fish tanks and flat-screen monitors playing underwater scenes. The menu contains a few comfort-food offerings like spareribs and mac and cheese, but the main draws come from the sea: plump steamed mussels in a creamy, spicy coconut-curry broth with cilantro and red peppers, and whole trout stuffed with sweet crabmeat. Aside from being tasty, the portions are enormous and the prices affordable. And although the fare is upscale and the dress code is formal, the vibe here is more family-friendly than stuffy.

column7: Fans of Asian street food love the larger spin-off of chef David Chang’s massively successful Momofuku Noodle Bar. It’s a sleek, wood-paneled, 50-seat eatery that serves low-carb versions of ssäms, the Korean finger food Chang calls “Asian burrito.” Patrons order a ssäm the way they would a wrap—except here, lettuce provides the casing and pickled shiitakes, edamame and oysters are among the choice fillings. The menu, which changes daily, often includes a kid-pleasing version with tender pork, black beans and a hint of spicy red kimchi sauce.

column7: Most New Yorkers know to avoid eating in Times Square, but this 3,500-square-foot restaurant-arcade may lure you in. If you can pry your child away from the profusion of kid amusements (highlights include simulated race cars and Skee-Ball), you’ll find a full menu of massive entrées to sate your family’s appetites. Tots can grab a juicy burger with fries, chicken fingers, grilled cheese or pasta off the kids’ menu, then delve into the hot sugared doughnut holes with raspberry and chocolate dipping sauces. Parents should try the Cajun shrimp Alfredo or blackened-chicken pasta, and maybe dip into the ginormous drinks bible.

column7: The focus is clear as soon as you see the menu: This sleek, bustling, cobalt-hued eatery offers more than 100 varieties of crêpes—some savory, some sweet, all mouthwatering. We especially loved the rich and creamy spinach-and-mushroom crêpe; next time, we’ll experiment with Nutella or dulce de leche. For dessert, treat your tots to an enormous banana-split crêpe served with a scoop of ice cream and topped with chocolate sauce, whipped cream and sliced bananas. You could order a croque-monsieur for lunch, an omelette for brunch or lobster ravioli for dinner, but then you’d be missing the point.

column7: Those in search of a healthy meal can stop reading right now: Even the veggies (like broccoli, asparagus, string beans and okra) are coated in butter. But caloric concerns aside, the soul food served here is among the best on the Upper West Side, and portions of the artery-clogging stuff are more than generous. Kids can choose from downsized versions of the regular menu’s fried catfish strips, pulled pork, fried chicken and baby back ribs. Every entrée arrives with a choice of two sides, such as sweet candied yams and gooey macaroni and cheese. Save room for dessert: Enormous slices of homemade coconut-pineapple and red velvet cakes are worth forfeiting the last few savory bites of your main course.

column7: Got a kid going through a serious chicken-finger phase? At this buzzed-about takeout and delivery place, chicken (all free-range and organic) is the star—and rightly so. The tiny open kitchen churns out brined, double-battered, deep-fried chicken that’s moist inside and dark brown outside, cooked until it’s crisp. A lonely-looking rotisserie in back serves up a less fatty option for those who want it, and there’s always a veggie-of-the-day among the Southern-inspired sides. The homemade “bad-ass” cookies are not to be missed.

column7: This New England–style fish shack, named for chef-owner Marc Murphy’s favorite surfing spot, is sophisticated and sleek—no seaside knickknacks here. They don’t take reservations, but the kitchen keeps dinerlike hours, and the menu is packed with classics like mac and cheese, hot dogs and hamburgers. The restaurant doesn’t outdo nearby Pearl’s or Mary’s on the shellfish front, but it holds its own with the $29 lobster roll, a mound of luscious chopped meat mixed with scallions, tarragon and aioli and served on a soft roll with a side of sweet-potato chips.

column7: This French addition to the otherwise unexceptional stretch of Columbus Avenue between 81st and 86th Streets does enoughthings well to make it stand out. The decor is standard bistro—diners are surrounded by distressed mirrors and vintage ads. And the menu follows suit, listing all the expected staples: escargots, steak tartare, foie gras, steak frites. Although there’s not much on the menu for young tykes, older children can choose from nonintimidating items like a meaty sirloin burger with fries. A $15 prix-fixe brunch, served Saturdays and Sundays until 3pm, is predictably packed.

column7: Jeff Lederman, a Cobble Hill dad and owner of the juice bar Nectar, packs his menu here with creative and reasonably priced small plates and sandwiches. Junior diners happily choose from dishes on the children’s menu—including pasta with marinara sauce, accompanied by a juice box and chocolate-hazelnut pudding—or the main menu (velvety veal-and-porcini meatballs served on crusty white bread are justifiably popular). Bocca Lupo provides such a grown-up experience that you can almost forget you’re dining out with people who haven’t yet learned to tell time.

column7: Walk into this cacophonous, 5,000-square-foot space and you’ll see a video installation by artist Jon Kessler, bright red ceilings and walls, globe-shaped lamps made of bamboo sticks and floor murals of pink-and-green lotus flowers. The menu is equally over the top and includes soups, salads, fried rice, noodle dishes and vegetarian options, seafood, meat, poultry, curries and various types of sushi—80 offerings in all. Many are good; some are excellent. The shrimp roll is filled with plump crustaceans, springy vermicelli, and fresh mint and lettuce. Children will love the cushy circular booths, big enough for the whole family.

column7: Cajun-Italian hybrid Two Boots of Brooklyn is, of course, an institution, its comfy back room sporting red booths, a Mardi Gras mural and Christmas lights. Dishes like cornmeal-fried oysters evoke the bayou, but pizza is the main attraction for kids. Happy-face pies with tomato slices for eyes are an obvious choice, though gourmet tots may enjoy topppings like crawfish or Cajun meatball. Got pizza fatigue? Dig into hearty blackened catfish with mashed potatoes.

column7: For a mere $14 at lunch and $24 at dinner, sample the staggeringly long and comely buffet at Todai (formerly Minado), a capacious Japanese dining hall just east of Koreatown. Here, Japanese staples like miso soup, veggie tempura, edamame, chicken teriyaki and sushi accompany more-offbeat fare like yakisoba noodles, grilled squid, baked New Zealand mussels and buffalo wings with an Asian twist. Don’t miss the dessert bar, which parades a selection of mini cheesecakes, creamy pudding cups and quivering Jell-O cubes. It’s, ahem, Todai-for.

column7: Husband-and-wife team Caesar and Sarita Ekya turn out 12 varieties of mac and cheese that range from simple all-American (mild enough for picky pre-K types) to a more complex dish—with Brie, roasted figs and shiitakes, or mac and La Mancha with fennel and shallots. There’s a size for everyone: “nosh” (great for kids), “major munch” (a hearty adult serving) and “mongo” (if you want leftovers). A generous “partay!” size serves eight to 12 lucky folks. Children are offered a regular bowl in lieu of the sizzling skillet in which meals are typically served. The line can be frustratingly long, but for M&C fans, the food is worth the wait.

column7: Red-sauce joints aren’t exactly fashionable, but this pasta palace embraces the label. Frank and Dino provide the soundtrack, and the menu, too, comes straight from the Italian-American playlist. Kids chow on basic pasta like penne with marinara sauce, three-cheese ravioli or spaghetti with beef-and-veal meatballs—be aware that one generous order can easily fill three small bellies. While waiting for food to arrive, tots can be distracted by Italian movies shown on multiple television sets. Desserts, like homemade chocolate-chip gelato and peach sorbetto, exceed expectations.

Youngsters will eat up this little joint—even if they can’t eat in it.

column7: Father-and-son team Harry and Peter Poulakakos knew what they were doing when they opened this family-welcoming, 24-hour diner in an unusual location--the desolate-at-night Financial District. With its neon signs and leather-and-vinyl banquettes in primary colors, it looks like something you’d stumble upon in Times Square. Its kitchen-sink-type menu is clearly designed to appeal to a diverse set. Kids and adults alike should relish an appetizer of truffled mac and cheese. Then, dig into a hefty, decadent ice cream sandwich made with soft chocolate-chip cookies and creamy vanilla ice cream. Haute cuisine it’s not, but everyone from families to college kids to tourists looking for a pit stop will find something appealing here.

column7: Park Slope’s recent addition, the NoNO Kitchen (that’s North of New Orleans to you), offers roasted alligator sausage with a zippy splash of Creole mustard sauce. The spicy dish ($7), served up by chef Gregory Tatis, a disciple of Nawlins culinary legend Paul Prudhomme, tastes suspiciously like...well, sausage. The spicy meat finds its complement in the restaurant’s crunchy crawfish popcorn, crusty-top macaroni and cheese, and buttery candied yams, which are all likely candidates for NoNO’s new kids’ menu coming this spring.

column7: All too often, NYC hotel restaurants have a haughty vibe and cuisine to match. Not so at Fireside, a new eatery from chef Sam DeMarco (First, Merge, District) inside the Omni Berkshire Place. The open, airy space, which seats 80, is decorated with red leather booths and large Lucite boxes meant to serve as hanging fireplaces (pending approval from the New York City fire marshal). The restaurant is open for breakfast (á la carte and buffet), lunch and dinner seven days a week. Adults can nosh on playful New American dishes such as foie gras candy apples, short-rib tacos, escargot profiteroles, pizzette and barbecued-pork “osso buco,” as well as black and white chocolate mousse cake for dessert; children can choose from a kids’ menu that includes chicken bites, crustless grilled cheese and hot chocolate with homemade marshmallows. In keeping with the pyro theme, menus are shaped like oversize matchbooks. Sounds like a hot spot indeed.

column7: This friendly, unassuming restaurant boasts an impeccable pedigree: It’s a collaborative effort from Craig Samuel (City Hall) and Ben Grossman (Picholine). Seating is comfy and simple—bare wooden tables indoors and on a glass-enclosed porch. Most meats are dry-rubbed and all are served alongside a trio of sauces (Jointsmoke, Hollapeno and Brown Sugar–Chile). The short ribs and pulled pork sandwich are both standouts. For a simple yet seductive surprise, try the iceberg wedge served with chunky blue-cheese dressing; it’ll tempt you to lick the plate—really.

column7: Children can order mini-burgers and a nest of crispy shoestring fries at this glossy, spacious patty shack near Union Square. So pop into this joint from restaurateur Jonathon Morr (Republic, Bond St) and indulge your kid’s fast-food cravings. You can happily join him with a few (very big) bites of the classic: a jumbo beef burger with red onion, lettuce, tomato, pickle, ketchup, Dijon mustard and cheddar on an equally jumbo bun—ours had lots of jus to spare.

column7: Explore the various cuisines of Brooklyn without ever setting foot in the borough at this Times Square eatery (or its Carnegie Hall cohort), where the menu ricochets back and forth from red-sauce Italian to buttery noodle kugel to other old-world delicacies, all in ginormous portions. Where else are you going to see a so-called 15-bite all-beef hot dog served on a brioche bun with spicy mustard, sweet pickle relish, sauerkraut and onions rings for $15.95? If the menu doesn’t fascinate your little ones, the baseball-themed, wood-paneled space definitely will.

column7: The pressed sandwiches (or “swiches”) at this lime green mini-cafeteria are twice as good as the panini you’ve been attempting to whip up at home. Humdrum grilled cheese receives unprecedented flavor (and crunch) in the double-decker version made with Gruyere, cheddar and sliced beefsteak tomato on perfectly warmed rye bread. While kids should have no trouble gobbling down any number of the savory options here, our pick for a real treat is the sweet and sticky Memphis, made with peanut butter, sliced bananas and honey on grilled golden-raisin semolina bread. Balance out the sweetness with a bag of potato chips; made on the premises, they have just the right amount of spice and, surprisingly, aren’t greasy.
