column7: A roomier version of its West Village namesake (210 W 10th St at Bleecker St, 212-741-7971), this all-American spot serves some of the freshest comfort food in town. The specialties are oh-so-thick milk shakes, juicy cast-iron-cooked turkey burgers and a slew of grilled hot dogs topped with relish, cheese, grilled onions or chili. Kids may beg for the giant Oreo cookies stacked behind the counter, but with a little cajoling you might get them to fill up on healthier fare first. Long, crispy french fries may be replaced with a side of vegetables from the eatery’s signature seasonal market, which features a rotating list of fresh produce, from Brussels sprouts and broccoli to fennel, kale and bok choy.

column7: Designer ingredients elevate this Park Slope doggeria above other fast-food stops. One wall of the petite rectangular space bears a bright blue, orange and yellow hot-dog mural; diners can sit on cheddar-cheese-hued plastic chairs to nosh on a dizzying variety of tube steaks. On offer are six types of dogs, among them the Mutt (all-beef franks with natural casing), the Best-in-Show (grass-fed beef), the Bird Dog (chicken or turkey) and the veggie-friendly Downward-Facing Dog (tofu), as well as a wealth of toppings and three choices of bun. Desserts are decadent, but we think the sweetest thing about this place is the photo collection of rescued canines that lines its walls.

column7: Not only does chef-owner Melanie Schrimpe arrive bright and early to make all the goodies in her tiny Billyburg bakery, she also works the register. And customers are grateful for Schrimpe’s devotion. The former Magnolia Bakery manager turns out superb treats: everything from a fresh lemon tart (for the kids) to surprisingly addictive sea-salt-and-espresso cookies (for you). Muffins, scones and the ever-popular cupcakes are also high on the must-eat list.

column7: If the idea of dining in tourist-laden South Street Seaport with a kid in tow makes you weak in the knees (and not in a good way), check out this gem of a restaurant. Just slightly off the beaten cobblestoned path, Nelson Blue serves fantastic New Zealand-style grub in a beautiful space; you’ll feel like a Kiwi yourself, surrounded by all the native tribal decor. Kids will go for the skewers of traditional choices like lamb and pork. Finger-friendly sides include zucchini-and-corn fritters and french fries with herb salt. The service will have you relaxed and ready to face the Seaport crowd--or eager to stay put for another round.

column7: Winter, surprisingly, is a great time to go to Coney Island. The amusement park may be closed, but lines at the aquarium, open 365 days a year, have dwindled. After a visit, the hearty food in the Russian community of neighboring Brighton Beach makes an ideal end to a chilly day. The menu at Cafe Glechik is a perfect example: the homey Russo-Ukrainian restaurant specializes in pelmeni and vareniki, which are basically Slavic takes on ravioli—and what kid doesn’t like stuffed pasta? The small, wontonlike vareniki can be ordered as a savory entrée (a potato-filled version, for instance, comes with mushrooms and onion on top) or as a dessert (we preferred the one stuffed with cherries). Even better, perhaps, is pelmeni Moscow, a very white dish in which ample potato dumplings are doused in a cheese-and-butter sauce, then baked in a crock, creating a thin, yummy crust. Many dishes here come in a crock, like the Odessa stew (beef and potatoes in a rich gravy). Make sure to wash it all down with “compote,” a refreshing drink made of cherries, apples and pears—fishing out the chunks of fruit is part of the fun In a nice touch for grown-ups, the cappuccinos come in a tall glass that reveals elegant, painstakingly poured layers of coffee, milk and froth.

column7: This classic Brooklyn pizza joint—think no-frills booths with Formica tables, and plenty of delivery and to-go orders—offers an array of menu options from pressed sandwichesto pastas and salads, but pizza is the prime attraction here. Husband-and-wife owners David and Lourdes O’Keefe bill their stellar grilled pizzas (with superthin, chewy crusts and just the slightest bit of char) as “personal size,” though at six slices they’re easily big enough to feed two hungry kids. We liked one with chunks of sweet sausage, grilledred and yellow peppers, onions and cloudsof soft ricotta; the traditional tomato, mozzarella and basil is a good choice for picky eaters.

column7: We did our best to rule out chains, but when we discovered that some of the city’s top soup spots (including Amy’s Bread, Murray’s Bagels and Park Slope’s Tea Lounge) actually serve Hale and Hearty, we knew we had to include this one’s home base in Chelsea Market. With close to 150 made-on-the-premises soups (about 17 are offered at any given time) and a focus on fresh ingredients–all the corn they use is shucked by hand, for instance–even the most devoted repeat customers are bound to find a new variety to try, as we did recently with the spinach-artichoke-cheddar concoction (verdict: superb). Seafood fans, vegans, chowder devotees and chicken-and-vegetable-only tots will all find something to love, and the staff is generous with tastings. At this location, you can get a glimpse into the kitchen that generates the entirety of the company’s production, with 3 million portions last year alone. The only downside is the price ($5-$9 for 16 ounces); strangely enough, you’ll pay less at those other eateries that serve Hale and Hearty (which, by the way, we love no less just because they have good taste in soup).

column7: This vegetarian spot, like Candle 79 a few blocks away, caters to people who are vigilant about what enters their bodies (even helpings that contain honey are clearly marked). For a delicious, if fiery, dish, try the renowned grilled seitan chimichurri in citrus-cilantro marinade, served on skewers. Tamer types will wolf down the veggie lasagna, and little ones we know swear by the vanilla soy ice cream ($3 for one scoop).

column7: Maybe everyone’s too busy clawing their way into nearby Pastis to realize that a primo brunch spot awaits here. Start off with the filling grilled corn on the cob, rubbed down with chile aioli and queso cotija, followed by spicy migas, a mess of scrambled eggs with chorizo, crispy tortilla chips and jalapeño coulis. Peanut-butter-and-jelly quesadillas and mini beef hard-shelled tacos off the kids’ menu come to the rescue for milder palates.
column92: 73 Gansevoort St at Washington St
column144: Subway: A, C, E to 14th S; L to Eighth Ave

column7: During a torrential downpour, my mother-in-law and I walked into the former Shopsin’s space with my two-year-old son and three-month-old daughter. The host escorted us through the entryway grocery, which offers a variety of prepared foods and gourmet fixings for a home-cooked meal,and into the rustic dining area.Our server found a place to park our double stroller (no eye-rolling, no forcing us to fold it up). At first the menu seems too sophisticated for a toddler, but I found tasty, uncomplicated entrées such as baked chicken or a simple piece of cod, plus french fries and hush puppies, to sate the white-food set. The dish that made my heart sing was the gnocchi with short ribs, escarole and Parmesan broth (pictured): Not only would we survive this outing, but I’d also get to eat an adult meal.Because the restaurant was bustling enough to cover up my son’s rising voice and my baby’s tired cries, we braved dessert. The chocolate–banana bread pudding with bourbon syrup and whipped cream had a pleasing, cakey texture and both looked and tasted divine.We had just about dried off from the rain by the end of the meal. The staff helped us with the stroller and thanked us, with genuine warmth, for coming. Really, it was our pleasure.
column8: NYCVisit: TrendsetterEat Out Award Winner

column7: The founders of this Boerum Hill ice cream parlor aim to do more than just sell great frozen treats. They’ve also invested in eco-friendly practices and want to educate consumers on the origins of their sweets. Alexis Miesen and Jennie Dundas, first-time restaurant owners, have recruited fourth-generation ice cream maker Matt White to churn up 16 flavors of superpremium at local Ronnybrook Dairy just for the shop, and they source their chocolate from a cooperative in Ghana. Rounding out the menu is coffee from Dutchess Country purveyor Irving Farm and high-end In Pursuit of Tea brew; pastries, sandwiches and other snacks are in the works, all to be served with biodegradable cutlery. The duo’s shop, built in part with reclaimed lumber, isn’t simply a place to grab a cone: Parents can enjoy indoor seating and free Wi-Fi service, while kids work off their sugar buzz in the play area at the back at the space.

column7: Co-owner Erwin Schrottner--a native of southern Austria and an alum of fancier spots like the Monkey Bar--named the place for one of his three young daughters, and it seems he had them in mind when devising the menu. The lineup includes simple but precisely prepared beer-hall staples: house-made bratwurst, spaetzle, fluffy quark (cheese) dumplings, tangy pickles and fresh-baked soft pretzels. The kitchen is happy to make adjustments to dishes (bacon in your spaetzle? Sure!). Click here

column7: At this spacious sibling of the cherished Clinton Street Baking Company, strollers and a Columbia crowd compete for a chance to enjoy the organic-heavy menu. Fluffy pancakes teem with succulent wild Maine blueberries, and warm farro porridge with dried fruit, almonds and honey will have kids renouncing their Quaker oats. While waiting for that coveted seat, slake your little ones’ thirst at the juice bar.

column7: At little Italy’s newest treat shop, kids can ogle more than swirled lollipops and tins of exotic hard candies. column7: The menu reads like an omnivore’s list of favorite foods—fried calamari, lamb schnitzel, seared tuna niçoise salad, ricotta gnocchi, vegetable bibimbap and four cuts of steak—but somehow it works. Families will feel welcome here, and not just because the acoustics drown out even a colicky baby’s wails, or because the menu is loaded with kid fare like mac and cheese and spaghetti and meatballs. We’ll be back for the beer-battered string beans and, for dessert, the Pink Pussy Cat (one of eight sundaes)—an intoxicating mix of red velvet cake, strawberry ice cream, fresh strawberries and whipped cream. column7: Jackson Heights residents have no problem satisfying a dosa craving, a taco jones or a taste for Peruvian rotisserie chicken. But until recently, the area lacked a comfy java joint.Enter Espresso 77. The petite, cheerful spot—four white tables, a dozen blue chairs (plus two window seats), orange walls and a pressed-tin bar—already feels like a neighborhood fixture. On a recent Monday morning, a pair of nannies sat with their charges; soon after, two stroller-wielding moms stopped in. A bulletin board advertises nearby yoga classes, and both a new-mothers’ group and a knitting circle regularly meet in the space.The homey menu befits the community vibe. Breakfast treats include moist, crumbly scones from the Heights’ Ambrosia Bakery; among the unusual varieties is the pancetta-Gruyère, a sweet-salty combo. Velvetty lattes and other barista concoctions made with beans from Ithaca, New York’s Gimme! Coffee provide a refreshingly noncorporate pick-me-up. At lunchtime, a changing roster of homemade soups, panini and wraps round out the offerings; the chicken curry wrap hit just the right balance of creaminess and spice. On weekends the place gets packed, so if your schedule permits, bring the clan by on a weekday and check out the artwork on display: The rotating exhibitions, naturally, highlight the work of locals.—Carolyn Juris

column7: The kosher oasis, founded in 1954, has left its longtime East Village location and resettled in Murray Hill. Steer kids toward old favorites like noodle pudding, supermoist brisket and fruit blintzes with sweet maple syrup, or new options like miniburgers and franks-in-blankets, any of which tots can wash down with a glass of fountain-pulled chocolate soda. The famed deli sandwiches are large enough to split among three children or two adults; they arrive with a basket of rye bread that makes divvying up the house-cured corned beef (superior to the pastrami and salami) as easy as gobbling it down. column7: To paraphrase Kermit the Frog, it’s not easy being ecologically responsible. This new Park Slope store can help you get dinner on the table and do your part for the planet. Seasonal, pre-prepped meals include options like roasted pork chops with apples and cider glaze ($30) or crispy fish cakes with lemon aioli and frisee salad ($16), and are made with locally sourced, organic ingredients whenever possible. The dinners, which serve two to three people, are packaged in biodegradable “eco-tainers” that can be returned for composting.

column7: DUB Pies’ second Brooklyn outpost, the Pie Shop is just a block from Prospect Park. Now that spring is here, it’s a boon for family picnics. Like those at the original Columbia Street location, the self-contained meals, a staple in New Zealand and Australia, come with kid-pleasing fillings surrounded by a delectable crust—flaky outside and moist inside. My picky four-year-old gave his “steak mince” (ground beef) pie a suspicious look, turned it over a few times, then dug in with a gusto usually reserved for Halloween candy. The flavorful sausage roll, which resembles an elongated pig-in-a-blanket, was another hit with both of my boys. I preferred the surprisingly sophisticated and creamy vegetarian-curry pie, with the peppery chicken a close second. For dessert, we split a moist Lamington, another Down Under classic—jam-filled sponge cake covered with chocolate icing and shredded coconut.Staffers are friendly—and they pour a great cup of coffee—but since the sunny corner shop has just three small tables, you may prefer to order your pies to go. If so, thoughtful extras include insulated bags to keep them warm, and reheating instructions so that your family can enjoy the treats at home.

column7: The high chairs stacked against one wall promise that kids are welcome in the sophisticated, earth-tone dining room. Try the flaky Tuscan pizza tart topped with spinach-walnut pesto, roasted eggplant and soy cheese, or a crispy black-eyed pea cake with chipotle aioli. Raw zucchini “linguine” (julienne veggies stand in for pasta) is as appealing as the real thing, and the chocolate soy ice cream shake with gobs of peanut butter puts Reese’s to shame.

column7: In the most child-friendly union since Brad and Angelina, the folks behind the erstwhile Pinch (Pizza by the Inch) and the East Village’s S’MAC (Sarita’s Macaroni and Cheese) have joined forces. The result is lacto-carb heaven. Fun fare like pizza topped with hot dogs and cheeseburger-infused macaroni has major kid appeal. Adults will appreciate delectable dishes like S’MAC’s Parisienne, which combines Brie, figs, roasted shiitake mushrooms and fresh rosemary, or a savory pizza with chicken sausage and chorizo. Bonus: Wine and beer are available. Treat yourself—it’s worth the extra 15 minutes on the treadmill.

column7: Walk into this retro soda fountain and be transported to the borough’s Neil Simon–esque past. Take a seat on one of the spinning stools at the counter, or on a bench if you’re with an unsteady toddler, and introduce your tot to classics like egg creams, lime cherry rickeys and malted milk shakes. Lunch fare is more 2009 than 1959—a crisp and buttery panino-style grilled cheese, a turkey sandwich with Swiss, avocado, bacon, jalapeño and pesto on focaccia, or a ham (or turkey) and cheese with strawberry slices. Other offerings include homemade soup, croissants and java from Park Slope’s Gorilla Coffee.

column7: Don’t mistake this buzzed-about Los Angeles transplant for a garden-variety TCBY. First, there’s the hip, minimalist decor layered with kid-friendly surfaces for unexpected spills. And then there’s the suitably hip, minimalist menu: only three flavors (plain, pomegranate and green tea). Parents who want to sneak something healthy into their child’s dessert can choose from a plethora of tasty fruit add-ons—strawberry, pineapple, raspberry, blueberry, blackberry and more. Check the website for additional NYC locations (15 in total, and counting) and beware the scary, scary lines.

column7: The menu at this neighborhood café incorporates as many locally sourced, seasonal and organic ingredients as possible; a bookshelf features the work of area authors. Kids may gravitate toward the peanut butter, banana and honey or Nutella and banana panini, and adults will appreciate the changing selection of salads—particularly the fregola with cucumber, mint, parsley, tomato and pumpkin seeds—and the “Red Neck,” a breakfast wrap with hominy grits, smoked ham, scrambled eggs and farmhouse cheddar. The homemade desserts are crowd-pleasers, especially the triple-chocolate brownies. Almost everything is made on-site, right down to the mayonnaise. Click here

column7: Does your kid want to taste every flavor at the ice cream parlor? Well, now he can. Yogurtland is the city’s first treatery to offer soft-serve that’s also self-serve. Tots can fill their cups with as many varieties as they want in whatever ratio they prefer (as long as their cup doesn’t, er, runneth over). We’re not sure which is the bigger thrill: pushing down on the dispensers’ levers or hitting up the bountiful toppings bar at the end.

column7: Dosas are the draw at this spacious, no-frills cafeteria in the Hindu Temple Society of North America. A mostly Indian crowd congregates here, with many kids in tow, for a carb (and mango lassi) fix. Children will have fun tearing off pieces of the crackling, potato-filled Pondicherry dosa; no need to disclose that the dahi vada—mushy doughnuts topped with yogurt—are made of lentils. Afterward, pop into the temple shop, where tots can amuse themselves with $2 Indian comic books.

column7: Like its neighboring sibling, Sweet Melissa Pâtisserie, the Crèmerie is a delightful temple of decadence. The Campfire Sundae is a kid-magnet for all seasons: graham crackers, toasted marshmallows, hot fudge and fresh whipped cream atop rich Bassetts ice cream. Grown-ups, when not dipping into their children’s dishes, may opt for a buttery caramel-and-rum-raisin-bread-pudding sundae or the espresso-soaked coffee ice cream garnished with candied lemon peel. Baked goods from the Pâtisserie, such as homemade brownies and Peanut Butter Indulgence (layers of chocolate cake, peanut butter and ganache), make welcome guest appearances in the sundaes. All of these treats, as well as cones, malteds and egg creams, can be ordered to go. Click here

column7: Head to this hangout for a true Neapolitan wood-fired pie. Fussy eaters might gravitate toward the classic Margherita, while adventurous adults can try the brussels-sprout-and-speck topping. Before devoting attention to the main attraction, trade bites of arugula salad with pears, figs, Gorgonzola and smoked bacon. Hot dog lovers can try a bold upgrade: thick slices of roasted mortadella.

column7: Carefully curated, seasonal fare reminds you what skilled hands can do with top-notch ingredients. This is apparent from your first bite of the slightly sweet, slightly salty popovers brought to the table in lieu of bread soon after you sit down; similarly, the delicata squash tart appetizer with house-made buttermilk ricotta is a creamy revelation. The attention to culinary detail extends even to the children’s meal, which finishes with a Blue Marble mini-sundae. After 7pm the place is mobbed, but for the two hours before that, you’ll have it to yourselves. The obliging staff won’t bat an eye at your picky eaters, or at tykes who can’t sit still.

column7: This venerable delicatessen, overstocked butcher and café is located in the city’s most beloved food-and-kitchen-supplies market. The glossy menu may paralyze your family with indecision; it lists more than 50 sandwiches, plus platters, pastas, soups, salads, stromboli and sides. Ingredients are of high quality, including Mike’s own soppressata and filet mignon bresaola. Let your kids try a little Italian nougat, if they’re feeling adventurous; and don’t miss peeking at the guys hand-rolling cigars out front.

column7: Carefully curated, seasonal fare reminds you what skilled hands can do with top-notch ingredients. This is apparent from your first bite of the slightly sweet, slightly salty popovers brought to the table in lieu of bread soon after you sit down; similarly, the delicata squash tart appetizer with house-made buttermilk ricotta is a creamy revelation. The attention to culinary detail extends even to the children’s meal, which finishes with a Blue Marble mini-sundae. After 7pm the place is mobbed, but for the two hours before that, you’ll have it to yourselves. The obliging staff won’t bat an eye at your picky eaters, or at tykes who can’t sit still.

column7: Those who choose to dine at the New York branch of the kitschy chain do so more for the atmosphere than for the menu selection, which comprises standard all-American, Kraft-singles-inspired plates. A stone’s hurl from the major Broadway theaters, the establishment boasts silver screen memorabilia (just try to tear your tween away from the Twilight case) and handprints left by visiting celebs (emo vamp Robert Pattinson and the Jonas Brothers, omg). But fear not, mom and dad: There’s also a full bar.
